title: Trapline Status
text:
The target is to have traps checked every 2 weeks. More than 50% of traps checked on a line is considered a minimum for the line status. The table below uses colour coding of;


less than 14 Days: green


14 - 28 Days: yellow


28+ Days: red


Expand any trap line to see who most recently checked, and when.

title: Kaitake Ranges Conservation Trust
text:
70 active trappers checking 824 traps over 27 trap lines.  


The Kaitake Ranges Conservation Trust is a community volunteer group that help manage and run the stoat and ferret trapping network in the Kaitake Ranges, which are the northern most part of Te Papakura o Taranaki/Egmont National Park. This network is used to protect the native species, including relocated/released kiwi that are now successfully breeding. If you’d like to see some of the critters and plants that are found in the Kaitake Ranges you can look through observations people have recorded on inaturalist.


This website is used to surface the catch data that we record in a way to make it easily accessible and useful to our members. New data is loaded every day; the last refresh was: 15-10-2025 07:49.

The site is made up of these sections:


Catch Summary: An overall summary of catches over time


Trap Summary: An interactive table for interrogating the status of traps and how well each trap is doing


Trap Line Status: An interactive table showing servicing history by trap line and highlighing whether lines are overdue for checks




These flags indicate if the load process is working:

title: Trap Summary
text:
This table gives some summary information for each trap within the trapping project. You can use the search box below each column header to filter on a specific item (e.g. a specific trap line, trap, date or last species caught).  Clicking on any of the column headers will allow you to sort. Keep clicking to toggle between ascending or descending. If you want to sort by more than one column, hold the shift button down when clicking any subsequent columns. Keep holding the shift button down if you want to reverse the sort order.  Examples on how you might use this table include;


Search for your trap line


Sort by last species caught (or use the search filter again) to find which traps catch the most or least of any species


Sort by last catch date to see which traps have caught recently and what species that was


Sort by days since last catch to see which traps haven’t had a recent catch


 You can expand the number of rows with the ‘Show’ drop down selection at the bottom of the table.

title: Catch Summary
text: A Summary of catches by year, and also the last 2 and 4 weeks with comparison to the 2 and 4 week windows for the same time of year from the prior year.
